content: The Act titled "Clean and Green Renewable Energy Tax Credit Act of 2007" extends and modifies the investment tax credit for solar energy property and qualified fuel cell property. The "Clean and Green Renewable Energy Tax Credit Act of 2007" extends and modifies the investment tax credit for solar energy and fuel cell property by amending relevant sections of the Internal Revenue Code to extend deadlines to 2031 and adjust applicable percentages. The investment tax credit percentages for solar energy property are 30% for years 2007-2015, 25% for years 2016-2021, and 20% for years after 2021. Energy property now includes excess energy storage devices. Solar process heat, advanced energy storage systems, and solar lighting equipment including solar hybrid lighting systems are eligible for tax credits. Solar lighting equipment using fiber-optic distributed sunlight is included until January 1, 2031. Solar photovoltaic energy property credit is determined solely by kilowatt capacity. The energy credit for solar photovoltaic energy property is $1,500 for each half kilowatt of capacity, determined solely by kilowatt capacity. The text discusses amendments to the tax code regarding rehabilitated or subsidized property and the allowance of credits against the alternative minimum tax for specified investments. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2006, including the investment credit attributable to the energy credit under section 48. Extension and modification of credit for residential energy efficient property. Extension and modification of the residential energy efficient property tax credit include amending the termination date to 2016, removing the 30 percent allowance for solar electric property, capping the credit at $1,500 per half kilowatt of installed capacity, and expanding the definition of qualified solar water heating property expenditure. The amendment includes adding advanced energy storage systems as qualified photovoltaic property expenditures and allowing the credit against alternative minimum tax. The amendment includes adding advanced energy storage systems as qualified photovoltaic property expenditures and allowing the credit against alternative minimum tax. Section 55 of the tax code is amended to allow for the carryforward of unused credits to the succeeding taxable year. Conforming amendments are made to sections 25D, 23(b)(4)(B), and 24(b)(3)(B) of the tax code. Section 24(b)(3)(B) and Section 26(a)(1) of the tax code are amended to include sections 25D and 25B. These amendments apply to expenditures in taxable years starting after December 31, 2006. SEC. 4. 3-YEAR ACCELERATED DEPRECIATION PERIOD FOR SOLAR ENERGY PROPERTY AND FUEL CELL PROPERTY. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to property descriptions in certain clauses. It includes changes to section 168(e)(3) and section 48(a)(3)(A) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2006, specifically regarding wind energy substitution in the clause. SEC. 5 amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend the credit for electricity produced from certain renewable resources until 2014. SEC. 6 introduces an investment credit for small wind systems. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code extends the credit for electricity produced from renewable resources and introduces a 30 percent credit for small wind systems rated at 100 kW or less. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code introduces a 30 percent credit for qualified small wind system expenditures made by taxpayers during the taxable year, with a maximum credit of $1,500 for each half kilowatt of installed capacity. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code introduces a 30 percent credit for qualified small wind system expenditures made by taxpayers for equipment rated at 100 kW or less, used in a dwelling unit in the United States. The amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2006. The amendment extends the credit for nonbusiness energy property under the Internal Revenue Code from December 31, 2007, to December 31, 2009.
